block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''EVERYTHING ABOUT CAMP (ALMOST),'' an hourlong revue with scenes by Michael Slade and songs by numerous authors spoofing mess-hall menus, campfire ghost stories, swimming lessons and the exhortations of well-meaning moms and dads. Tada, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea. Today at noon and 2 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 1 and 3 p.m. Tickets: $12; children, $6. Information: (212) 627-1732. Reservations advised.

''LOS SUENOS DEL COQUI'' (''DREAMS OF THE COQUI''),'' a bilingual play about a tiny frog from Puerto Rico that dreams of becoming important, presented by Viva Stage as part of the AT&T Latino Arts Festival, Sunday at 2 p.m. at Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, off Exit 9E of the Grand Central Parkway, near Shea Stadium. The festival, through Aug. 13, will feature music, theater, dance and film. Children's programs are free. Information: (718) 760-0064

''A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S RAVE, OR, WHAT YOU WILL,'' a play written and performed by youngsters ages 12 to 18 participating in Looking for Shakespeare, a theater workshop. The production, presented by the Provincetown Playhouse and the New York University Program in Educational Theater, is set in a secret Manhattan dance club where a group of teenagers go to escape the summer heat. Today and tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street, between Third and Fourth Streets. For ages 10 and older. Free. Information: (212) 998-5867.

''MINOTAUR,'' a hip-hop version of the Greek myth presented by members of Urban Youth Theater, features rap, break dance and body rhythms. Henry Street Settlement's Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side, (212) 598-0400. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7. Tickets: $5.

''READING RAINBOW,'' a musical by Theaterworks/USA inspired by the PBS television series of the same title, is a lively adaptation of eight stories, ranging from a Mexican folk tale (''Borreguita and the Coyote'') to a parable about transcending sexual and racial stereotypes (''Amazing Grace.'') Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues. Today at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m.; tomorrow at 11 a.m. Free; tickets available, first come first serve, starting at 10 a.m. on the day of the performance. Information: (212) 642-6754.

''THE UGLY DUCKLING,'' a musical version of the fairy tale by Debra Kaye, with lyrics by Brenda Bell. Presented by Literally Alive at the Hitchcock-Rockefeller Auditorium, Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street. For ages 3 to 8. Today at 10 and 11 a.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., with art workshops (children will create decorations for the stage ) at 1. Through Oct. 1. Tickets: $15; $5 workshop fee. Group rates for 20 and more. Reservations: (212) 866-5170.

''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' the L. Frank Baum story, featuring a country-and-western score, Sundays through Aug. 20 at 1:30 and 3:30 p.m. Puppetworks at the Children's Aid Society, Greenwich Village Center Theater, 219 Sullivan Street, between Third and Bleecker Streets. For ages 3 and up. Admission: $8; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718) 965-3391.
Events

FISH-TIVAL, tomorrow from 2 to 6 p.m., celebrates marine life in the Hudson River. Children can take a walk through the River Project and, at 4 p.m., watch the Arm of the Sea troupe perform ''Rip Van Winkle on the River of Time,'' a show with life-size puppets. At Pier 26, at North Moore Street. Free. Information: (212) 533-7275.

FLAX HARVEST, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 3 p.m. at the Lefferts Homestead Children's Historic House Museum, Prospect Park, Flatbush Avenue near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 965-6505. The flax crop will be harvested from the garden in preparation for September's Harvest Fair. The Lefferts, the house's 18th-century owners, spun flax into linen, their main cash crop. (The seeds are used for linseed oil.) Also taking place Sundays through August, the storytelling series ''Summer Songs and Stories,'' at 2 and 3 p.m. Free.

INTERACTION, a summer acting workshop at the Sony Wonder Technology Lab, for youngsters 10 and older exploring technology through acting, ends its first session with free performances, tomorrow at 5 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. Youngsters in the program developed the concepts, plot, characters and scripts. The audience will see how the participants create virtual computerized backdrops on the 19-foot-high screen in the Sony Wonder High Definition Theater, 56th Street and Madison Avenue. The second session of 10 programs, which runs on Wednesdays and Fridays, will begin on Wednesday; fee, $150. Information: (212) 833-4698

''SONGS OF CENTRAL PARK,'' a free outdoor sing-along with Roslyn Burroughs, who will perform songs about Central Park from the early part of the 20th century, tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m., at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue. For ages 6 and older. Free. Information: (212) 860-1370.

''BEYOND CAT'S CRADLE.'' Twine and twigs are ingredients in workshops tomorrow at 1, 2 and 3 p.m. at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, to demonstrate how to play games and tell stories using string. Free with museum admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. For all ages. Information: (718) 273-2060.

STONE-CARVING DEMONSTRATIONS, tomorrow and Aug. 26 from 1 to 5 p.m. at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, in conjunction with ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of the artist's limestone carvings. The sculptor Chris Pellettieri will talk about stone carving and, at a worktable set with tools and materials, show the various stages of sculpture. Free. Information: (212) 595-9533.

''STORY CORNER: IN THE PARK.'' Children will explore entertaining things to do in the park and share their favorite park experiences, tomorrow at 4 p.m. on the first floor of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, next to the exhibition ''William Merritt Chase: Modern American Landscapes, 1886-1890,'' which includes the artist's renderings of parks. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

THUNDERBIRD AMERICAN INDIAN MIDSUMMER POWWOW, an annual intertribal dance competition with more than 40 Indian nations represented. Through Sunday at the Queens County Farm Museum, 73-50 Little Neck Parkway, Floral Park. Tonight, gates open at 6, with performances from 7 to 10; tomorrow, gates open at 10 a.m., with performances from noon to 5 p.m. and 7 to 10 p.m.; Sunday, gates open at 10 a.m., with performances from 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; children 12 and under, $3. Visitors may also tour the grounds of the museum, go on hayrides for $2 and buy American Indian foods and farm-grown organic produce. Free parking. Information: (718) 347-3276.
Exhibitions

''ANIMALS AS ARCHITECTS'' AND ''PIGTAILS AND HARD HATS,'' interactive exhibitions at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. ''Animals as Architects,'' through Sept. 3, features a home with walls of recyclable material and another with a secret tunnel, demonstrating that animals are concerned with human interests like energy efficiency and comfort. ''Pigtails and Hard Hats'' (through Aug. 28) uses the characters from ''The Three Little Pigs'' to teach about the construction industry. Summer hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. Information: (718) 273-2060.

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' Most children know exactly how to get there: turn on the television set at the right time. An alternative route leads to the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights, where an interactive traveling exhibition (through Sept. 3) recreates the set of the PBS series. Through Sunday, the museum is celebrating Bert's birthday, with visitors receiving special giveaways courtesy of the Web site sesamestreet.com. Summer hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 6:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Tuesdays. Suggested admission: $4. Information: (718) 735-4400.

THE INVENTOR CENTER, the Children's Museum of Manhattan, Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street. Recent products from the next generation of inventors: a car with helicopter blades, a mechanical glove that contains school supplies and a Duck-a-Phone, which quacks instead of rings. Filled with 10 computer workstations, the center is a high-tech idea laboratory in which children use software developed by the museum to realize their wildest dreams. Each hourlong workshop is limited to children 6 and older accompanied by adults. The center offers six workshops a day; registration is required. Museum hours through Labor Day: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; infants under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.
